BAD Pc Port of a Decent Game...

Double Agent is probably my least favorite Splinter Cell game so far (comparing it to 1, Pandora Tomorrow, and Chaos Theory). Still, it is a good game if you can find a way to avoid all the game crashes and glitches.

It's too bad the pc port is so terrible. This is the first Splinter Cell pc game that I've had problems with. I made it halfway through the game with about 10 game crashes. Also, sometimes i run into a glitch where an invisible wall randomly appears in front of me to block my path. The safe-unlocking minigame is bugged as well. It took me a while to figure out that you have to have your movespeed set to 2 mouse-wheel ticks higher than the lowest in order to open a safe. Otherwise, the sensitivity is REAL high.

If I look past the port problems, there is a good game here. The missions provide decent environment variety. They added in a double-agent objective mechanic where you can choose what objectives to complete. Your decisions affect your trust with the Agency and the Terrorists. This is probably the most stealth-heavy title in the series so far, but it doesn't feel satisfying. Chaos Theory felt a lot better. The visuals also look worse than Chaos Theory for some reason.

Unfortunately, I don't think I will finish this game. I decided to quit halfway through because of all the game crashes and the inability to disable intro videos.

reviewText:
Summed Up: A really awful port to an otherwise pretty fun game. Buy this game on any other platform and you'll have a fun time, but avoid the PC version like the devil.

In-Depth: I'll start with the game itself. It's not going to be anyones favourite Splinter Cell as, quite frankly, it's one of the more linear and demanding of the series. Gone is the option to play the game your way and still get the best score if you complete the objectives; now the game ranks you on stealth. It provides penalties to how many guards you knock out/kill, locks you break etc. Meaning you have to basically be a shadow to get the best score. This is a fair idea, but the problem is, the level often throws enemies at you you HAVE to move out the way, or you have to do something ridiculously convoluted to get them to move; which just takes up way too much time.

Also introduced is the trust system; a fine line you have to take between both the terrorists and your employers. Alot of people were kind of iffy on this, but I honestly liked the idea. The main issue stems from the fact it's completely pointless. There are enough side objectives and such that you'll honestly always have full trusts 99.9% of the time; even on hard mode where you lose trust more and gain less. If they had made it much more imperitive to the game and maybe had it so you gained rewards from having certain levels, or even something as simple as dialogue change, it might have been  a worthy addition. As it stands, it's just kind of there; a nice idea that dosen't realise it's full potential.

As for the core game, it's pretty much Chaos Theoy's mechanics again. This is fine as, in my opion, Chaos Theory really got it right when it came to the stealth aspect and design; n both games have a nice, easy to navigate ingame inventory, the layouts easy to see etc. One major gripe thought is that they changed the stealth meters; as in, they no longer exist. In Chaos Theory, they had two bars which showed your visibility and sound. This was useful as it indicated how alert enemies where sound wise and indicated clearly how sneaky you were being. In this game, you have a light, that's it. It's green when your safe, yellow when not, and red when spotted. The problem is, while it takes into account shadows and does change when enemies are more alert, it never shows how much noise your making; which can be a HUGE problem if your next to an alerted enemy and want to sneak past him QUIETLY. But, that aside, it is for all intents and purposes just more of Chaos Theory sanded down. Back handed as that is, I'm not complaining at  a few more levels.

Now for the crux of the problem; the PC Port. The best summary would be 'A glitched up mess that everytime I play I find another'. The most common one is random crashes and lost autosaves, but there are weirder ones. Lost sound, not gaining your bonus equipment, a door not supposed to be there stuck in another door (Yes, that actually happened), do I need to go on? Not to mention graphically, the game just looks off. There is a guide to tweak this on steam, but the fact you HAVE to do this is pretty appaling; without the tweaks, the game looks... well, off, it's hard to explain, kinda like the world is slowly falling away pixel by pixel in the background. There are alot of things in this port that just make it dissapointing, and I really tried to look past them. But the bugs really were the final straw. Avoid the port like the devil, patches have been known to exist, but wether they work is apparently 50/50. Go buy another version of the game elsewhere; you'll be glad you did

I bought this in a steam sale with the other Splinter Cell games. After really enjoying Chaos Theory, I had very high hopes for Double Agent.

The first sign of trouble was the game did not support 1080p.  Chaos Theory from two years prior did, but Double Agent did not.  Instead, I was stuck with 720p.

Double Agent suffers from bugs and graphical issues throughout the game.  The lighting engine went from being very powerful and realistic to downright terrible.  The designers also removed fun features such as the sound meter and degrees of light.

Everything has been dumbed down in this game.  To make the UI more minimal, the light meter is now green for hidden, yellow for visible, and red for spotted.  Half the time you'll be standing in total darkness and have it still be yellow.

The PC port of Double Agent also crashes horribly.  Expect it to freeze up when loading requiring you to restart your computer.  Like previous Splinter Cell games, it lets you save wherever you are in the level.  Unlike previous Splinter Cell games though, there is no way of sorting your saved games.  So expect to have to dig through all your saves when you are trying to find the one you are looking for; there is no way to sort them.

Lastly, the gameplay is horrendous.  Half the missions take place during the day and are better played like a first person shooter than a stealth game.  Just shoot everything, don't bother with stealth.

I had high hopes for Double Agent and was sorely disappointed.  Don't buy this game!  Just read the synopsis and move on.

reviewText:
A very average game plagued by countless, strange bugs. Yes, it's the 4th Splinter Cell and one of the ♥♥♥♥♥iest pc ports you can get on PC. Even while patched (which, for some stupid reason, you have to do yourself since the Steam version is unpatched), the game has its bugs. AI tends to mess up, though that's one of the rarer bugs. Sometimes you fall through the floor. Sometimes an objective or the like can't be finished. For some reason, I couldn't use my goggles in some missions unless I whistled first - which you know, tends to attract guards. So yeah, sometimes I had to whistle in order to turn on my friggin' night vision goggles. That's one weird bug.

Bugs aside, this is an average game. As far as Splinter Cell titles go, this might just be the weakest. I also suggest you read up or play the previous games since they're excellent (especially Chaos Theory), as this review is written for those familiar with the stealth series.

The story is quite interesting in setup: after a mission in Iceland, Sam Fisher receives the news his daughter has been hit by a drunk driver. In order to help his friend, his superior Lambert decides to put him on a tough undercover assignment. Weird way to have your friend deal with grief, but alright. Lambert has him send to jail so he can befriend and assist in breaking out a known terrorist sympathiser, in order to join their group and become the double agent of the title. Sam is welcomed with open arms into the JBA (John Brown's Army, the terrorists) and sent on JBA missions almost right away.

And here we get to the main issue with the story: it's barely coherent, and barely there. So you go with your new terrorist buddy to the terrorist base... Any other game would introduce all the characters one by one, have you run around talking to people, basically set up the characters and the environment you will be spending 4 missions in (as the terrorist base acts as an inbetween mission hub). This game introduces a few characters with barely any dialogue, leads you straight to an obstacle course the terrorists want you to complete (with a timelimit!!), and to top that the NSA wants you to sneak around the base planting bugs. Calm your ♥♥♥♥ game, I just came here and barely know the place, now you want me to sneak around while the clock’s ticking? Can I at least know what this terrorist organization is all abo- OK OK I'M GOING TO TRY TO PLEASE THE JBA AND THE NSA SIMULTANEOUSLY RIGHT NOW.

The game operates on two trust meters: the NSA's and the JBA's, meaning the game has moral choices. It forces you to please both your actual employer (the NSA), and your new terrorist buddies. This means at certain moments, the game will have you choose between pleasing the JBA through EVULLLLL  and doing a nicer thing for the NSA, preventing either meter from depleting. This can lead to a few tense moments, at least one standing out, but these choices are far and few between and the lack of connection (due to lack of dialogue) to the characters means you won't give as much of a damn as you should. Also mind-boggingly stupid is that after the start of the game  Sam's daughter never ever pops up again in conversation. Why this had to be the catalyst for the game's events is beyond me.

Gameplay wise, it's also pretty weak. Gone are Chaos Theory's sound and shadow meters, which I had come to find a core element of the series' stealth mechanics. But no, in Double Agent you just get 3 states: invisible, visible, and spotted. There is some leniency with visible mode, as enemies far away will investigate, allowing you a stealthy retreat. But seriously, what was wrong with the stealth meter? Or the sound meter? Shadows are rather confusing: places that you'd think would give you thegreen light indicating invisibility instead make you light up like a Christmas tree and places you'd think make you stick out like a sore thumb make you invisible. The game's shadow contrasts make no sense, so there will be guesswork involved in whether a hiding place actually makes you hidden or not. As far as making sound goes, gone are masking environment sounds, and it's trial and error in finding out whether you're walking silently enough or not. It’s hit or miss with the game’s missions and moments.

Furthermore, this game has more cover based sneaking than the previous titles, amplified in the game’s daylight missions. I don't necessarily find that a bad thing: the gameplay flow of shadow hunting can be tiresome, so it's nice to break it up with cover to cover based sneaking, but it doesn't always work. The mechanics are built around shadows, so in the daylight missions you're going to come across situations where in a regular cover-based stealth game you'd be hidden, whereas here they see your head sticking out from behind a box or something. Again, more frustration.

When the game isn't just a frustrating affair with poorly defined stealth parameters, it can be fun and has its moments. It's just not up to par with Chaos Theory as it's back to trial and error gameplay, and stupid - sometimes gamebreaking - bugs can sour the experience.

Multiplayer is interestingly enough, still alive, though you won’t find anyone at random unless you’re in a lobby all day. Sadly, the game doesn’t have a coop campaign like I expected the game to have, since Chaos Theory had one. No, you’ll have to make do with the competitive mode. You’ll have to reach out to those few players keeping the MP alive. Once you’re in a game, it’s actually pretty fun. Spies VS. Mercs, the stealth-multiplayer competitive mode, is pretty cool. Spies are quick, nimble, agile and blend in the shadows (but have no guns to speak of), who either have to kill all the mercs or hack all the terminals in the level and get the hell away. Mercs try to prevent this, and do so in a first person mode with guns. Quite fun asymmetrical gameplay, though as with the SP, can be buggy, and tends to be laggy as well. Worth a try, really.

The singleplayer I can only really recommend for completionists. Supposedly, the PS2 and Xbox versions are quite different from the PC version and what it’s ported from: the original Xbox 360 game. These older-gen titles play out differently and are more similar to Chaos Theory gameplay-wise. I will have to try them out since hardcore fans seem to like them.

Play this to complete the Splinter Cell series, or to give a shot at the game's fun, though dying multiplayer mode.

This is the 4th episode in the Splinter Cell series.  You play as Sam Fisher, an operative in 3rd Echelon a top secret NSA black-op outfit.  Its all about stealth, not so much on killing.
If you haven't played any Splinter Cell game yet, what?  Where have you been.  These are great games.  However, you should not start with SC Double Agent.
This game is for SC veterans who want to do it all.  I started on this game three times.  Only the last time did I bite the bullet and stuck through.  Unfortunately compared to the previous SC games this one is slightly disappointing.

The good:
1. Decent stealth based action.  Shooting is not what its about and the shooting system has never been a strong point in any SC game - it is very static.

The bad:
2. Where is the luminosity meter?  Knowing when shadows are enough to cover you is a guessing game.
3. The choices you make have no discernable impact on the game.  Only the cut-scenes.
4. What is the story all about?  Some people want to blow up the USA, but why?
5. The characters are as thin as wet paper.  Sam's daughter is killed off at the start, why?
6. You unlock lots of equipment.  When do you actually get to use it?

The ugly:
7. Horrible stability issues.  My game crashed about five times per mission.
8. Character model getting stuck in the scenery.

Dam, in retrospect there where not many good points.  Thank goodness the game is relatively short.

reviewText:
6 out of 10

This is the 4th episode in the Splinter Cell series.  You play as Sam Fisher, an operative in 3rd Echelon a top secret NSA black-op outfit.  Its all about stealth, not so much on killing.
If you haven't played any Splinter Cell game yet, what?  Where have you been.  These are great games.  However, you should not start with SC Double Agent.
This game is for SC veterans who want to do it all.  I started on this game three times.  Only the last time did I bite the bullet and stuck through.  Unfortunately compared to the previous SC games this one is slightly disappointing.

The good:
1. Decent stealth based action.  Shooting is not what its about and the shooting system has never been a strong point in any SC game - it is very static.

The bad:
2. Where is the luminosity meter?  Knowing when shadows are enough to cover you is a guessing game.
3. The choices you make have no discernable impact on the game.  Only the cut-scenes.
4. What is the story all about?  Some people want to blow up the USA, but why?
5. The characters are as thin as wet paper.  Sam's daughter is killed off at the start, why?
6. You unlock lots of equipment.  When do you actually get to use it?

The ugly:
7. Horrible stability issues.  My game crashed about five times per mission.
8. Character model getting stuck in the scenery.

Dam, in retrospect there where not many good points.  Thank goodness the game is relatively short.

Add this with where autosaves and hard saves don't actually save, and you got yourself a piece of crap. I have given this game 7 chances (meaning I have restarted the game because of the issue with saves being deleted) and each time have recieved the same bugs and glitches.

Gameplay
Splinter Cell Double Agent is like every other Splinter Cell game. You stealth your way through each level and complete the set of objectives given to you without raising to much alarm or getting killed. Not to hard right? Well it is when game breaking bugs come into the picture. For example, in one level you are prompted to make mines, but before you start making the mines, you are supposed to listen to 2 people talk. I listened to the people talk, and when I went to make the mines, the mini game to make the mines didn't work properly. However, as little as I played, the game itself was an average stealth game.

Graphics
The games graphics are average in my opinion. They aren't anything spectacular, but I can forgive it for how long ago it came out.

Story
The story is rather mediocre. It's a story that countless spy movies and game have copied and pasted for years now and it's not very creative. In my reviews I don't tell plot summary, so if you want to read the story, look it up or read the description for the game.

Final Scores
Gameplay: 7
Graphics: 6
Story: 4
Overall: 5.7

reviewText:
I spent an entire week trying to get this game to work - was it worth it? Kinda.
Singleplayer is pretty linear and most of the levels are a drag; like who wants to sneak around in some African battlefield in broad daylight? Or hide behind tents and glaciers in Iceland? And don't get me started on those damn JBA missions...
There are some cool levels like when you escape from prison or blow up a cruise ship, but it still doesn't suffice for how boring the earlier segments are. The ending level is the most excitement you'll get from this game but you'll probably be bored out of your mind before you can get to it :D

Oh, and I forgot to mention, you get to make choices in this game. None of it really matters, though, because you don't really care for anyone that your choice affects so you're basically trying to be good (NSA) or evil (JBA) for no real purpose except for the ending, and there's only 1 true ending to this game (which happens to be the ending everyone hates), so the others are baloney.

Multiplayer is fun, probably the only redeeming thing this game has to offer but I won't go into that.

Conclusion:
Splinter Cell: DA is a subpar stealth game with a subpar story with subpar character with locations that are subpar for stealth -- but the multiplayer is good. 6/10

Side Note: The console version of this game (PS2, Wii, Xbox) is amazing, almost as good as Chaos Theory.

reviewText:
I loved Chaos Theory like a brother, but this might be the worst game I've ever played.

It's not just the glitches and the crashes. Alpha Protocol was buggy (though not as buggy as this), but I still love that game. I can get past a few bugs, but this game was broken from its inception. It's muddled in terrible, dumbed-down, counter-intuitive design. It's an insult to the brilliant design in the previous three. The horrible PC port was just the icing on the cake.

The first three games were reasonably paced, and emphasized a reliance on light and sound. If you were going to complete your mission, you needed to be a master of the shadows. In Double Agent, they dial it back to the lowest common denominator, and just make you hide behind conveniently placed objects. They try to pretend that light still plays a factor with a little yellow light on the back of your suit, but even when the light says you're concealed, enemies can still spot you from miles away. Direct concealment, and exploitation of predictable patrol patterns, is your only option out in the field.

But it's out of the field where it really hits the fan. In the JBA headquarters, Sam is tasked with skulking around the base and completing tasks for both the NSA and JBA, but doing so requires mastery of one of the worst level layouts in history. If you remember that 3D map that you never used in Chaos Theory, just because it worked so poorly that the game was easier to navigate without it, you'd be happy to know that it makes a triumphant return in Double Agent. Prepare to squint like your life depended on it, as you try to make heads or tails of all the different branching paths that lead to dead ends, and plot a precise route to your objective, only to be sent back to the drawing board when you come across a secuity door, and need to plot a new route to whatever grand McGuffin will unlock it. None of this is even challenging at all, it's just unbelievably tedious.

And that's my biggest problem with this game. It's so lazy, so insecure in its ability to give you a single, satisfying experience, that it just piles on busywork and hopes that'll keep you satiated. I do not play Splinter Cell to navigate through a cartoonish series of security doors, I play it for a challenging, satisfying stealth game. Double Agent is the complete opposite of everything the original three games stood for, and as a result, has none of what made them fun or interesting.

It's a horrible game even if you forgive the bugs, but they're still well worth mentioning. The game crashes during every mission, mandatory safe-cracking minigames don't function in any capacity, the frame rate dips and the graphics glitch out even on systems well above the system requirements, one snow mission near the beginning will run for maybe five seconds before giving you a BSOD, and some events will flat-out fail to trigger.

The first three Splinter Cell games had none of these problems (with the exception of a buggy shadow engine in Pandora Tomorrow, and one scripting bug in that same game that made me restart a level), and Chaos Theory somehow even had better graphics. Double Agent has no excuse. It's just a terrible game on every level.

The only thing this game has that's even remotely interesting is its morality system, and it's bare-bones at best. It's not a moral dilemma if the numbers on your screen clearely dictate what's the right choice. You aren't making hard decisions, you're just balancing stat bars, and like all the other busywork in this game, that isn't any fun. I know I already mentioned this game, but Alpha Protocol had a far better idea of what espionage morality entailed, on top of just being better, more inspired, more fun, and more functional than this game on every count.

Even for the more hardcore Splinter Cell fans, I wouldn't recommend this game. It's just horrible.

reviewText:
This is so bizarre.  I remember having this game on Playstation 2 back in the day and having fond memories of it and yet people keep saying this is not nearly as good as Chaos Theory.  While Chaos Theory is amazing I recall Double Agent having most of the same mechanics and an interesting undercover element.  So I install it to give it one more playthrough only to see what everyone was fussing about.  This is NOT the game I played on PS2.  Not by a long shot.  The missions are all different.  The story, the gameplay... Everything dumbed down.  As a long time fan of this series I was always confused by how so many people said this wasn't a good game.  Now I see why.

PC Double Agent is a very different animal to the console Double Agent in every way.  All the things I liked about the PS2 version is not here.  I enjoyed this game but despite its flaws and unlike all the other Splinter Cell games I have no desire to ever touch this one again.  The biggest problem was just how hard it was to avoid being spotted.  Like when you thought you were well hiddent and it turns out you weren't and there's no chance seeing it coming.  Enemies can spot you miles away and will shoot you instantly with pinpoint accuracy.  Sometimes through walls.  The undercover aspect between missions where you sneak around the terrorists base to do things during a time limit has been significantly dumbed down as well.  Oh get spotted in a restricted area Fisher you're not supposed to be here" with a little bump in trust.  I rememebr the stakes being much higher on PS2 with them shooting you on sight and better level design as well.  There just doesn't seem to be any tension in the stealth.   You either succesffully sneak through or you dont.  Half the time I would just go around a corner after being spotted and wait for the alert to go away after a second and its like nothing happened.  Oh noes my stealth score goes down?  I can't unlock gear that I'll never need?  pFFFFt say what you will about Conviction and Blacklist being more action oriented but at least those game's mechanics work well.

Edit: I didn't even talk about the crappy interface and other issues that plague this game.  When spacebar is your action button for everything from opening doors to turning light switches to grabbing guards from behind it makes sense to have a prompt on screen to let you know exactly what you're about to do.  All the games before this had it simply say it at the bottom of the screen.  Here its shoved in your face in the middle of the screen as if to say "YOU'RE ABOUT TO DO A THING JUST TO MAKE SURE YOU HAVE ADD AND CAN'T TELL"  As if thats not bad enough you can't use your mouse while hacking computers or reading emails.  You can't even type in the numbers when using a keypad lock!  Sometimes while opening safes it doesn't register the keys until you play with the mouse wheel for some reason.  Top it all off with glitches such as bodies flying away after you drop them completely destroying your efforts of hiding them.  On a couple occasions they just flopped around for minutes until enemies nearby noticed and i was screwed.  This doesn't even touch on the save issues when it doesn't read its own auto saves or in one mission reoloading a save causes the game to crash.  Its all these little problems littered throughought the game that just made it more of a hassle.  I mean Chaos Theory (the game before this) had gamepad support!  It didn't work very well.  It didn't register R2 and L2 on a PS3 controller but it was there.  This one has none.  Doesn't read the controller at all... How do you have so many downgrades?  Its so counter-intuitive to PC gaming when even the first Splinter Cell was more intuitive than this!!!!

This is the only game in the series where I will say skip it.  If you can get an old copy of a console version in a bargain bin somewhere go for that.  That version is far superior to this extreme change for no reason.  Makes no sense why they made two completely different games for different platforms.  For all I know the Xbox version is even more different so I would play it safe and just find a PS2 if you must play every game in the series."

reviewText:
Broken Cell Double Agent

After owning the first Splinter Cell for years but never finished it. I then bought the first 3 Splinter Cells on PC and finished all three of them a couple of years ago. Each one was fantastic though I felt that the shadows in Pandora Tomorrow were a little off but otherwise good. The game that stood out of the three however was Chaos Theory with hardly anything to critise about it. It had brilliant stealth mechanics, a great soundtrack, great level design, good story, supposedly good co-op (haven't played it) and of course the legendary spies vs mercs mode.

After three amazing titles, you would expect the 4th installment of the series to be able to live up to its predecessors right? Wrong!

This game makes me rage in so many ways! The game feels rushed and unfished, the first game had good stealth mechanics, it beats this in terms of stealth mechanics by far which means that this isn't just a step back, this is a few jumps backwards. There are rarely any proper shadows in this which means that the only way you can tell if you're invisible is by looking at the indicator either on your back or in the bottom left hand corner of your screen; if it is green you're invisible, if it's yellow, you are visible and are at risk of being detected and if you are red then you better run mofo because you're about to get your backside handed to you.

This sounds like an okay system and may have been more acceptable had the light metres in the previous games never existed, but the problem with it is that the shadows aren't dark enough most of the time like they were in the previous titles which makes running into the shadows game of chance as either it will hide you or it won't, it's not obvious when you're about to enter an invisible area and because of this, I was constantly being detected in absolutely rediculous ways which was not fun at all and because of this I was constantly autosaving way more than I would of needed to in the earlier splinter cells, I think on average I autosaved about 55 times per level.

The story however is actually good and I did enjoy it, what this game does offer that the previous titles did not were the ability to make choices in the game and making those choices would result in different outcomes which would give the game more replay value if the gameplay wasn't so bad.

But one of the biggest problems I have with the game is it's incredibly bad PC port, it is so sloppy despite it being the same version of the game as the xbox 360 and the PS3. Why is it so bad? it crashes constantly for no reason and I have quite a high spec 3 month old pc and this is 2014, the game is so badly optimised and it is absolutely outrageous that ubisoft haven't fixed it, I'd hate to think what would happen if I were to run this on my old computer with 10 year old hardware.

The menu system in the game is annoying and every time you want to hack into a computer or look under a door, you have to watch this stupid animation on your opsat which lasts 3 seconds, that might not sound that bad but when you have to watch it so regularly and it's the same animation over and over again it really gets frustrating.

I've also heard that Spies Vs Mercs was completely ruined in double agent which is just another reason not to like the game so just throwing that out there.

Oh, and every time you either want to hack a safe or the mine assembly (both of which are annoying events that you have to do), make sure that you are in running mode as the game was so badly ported from console that when you try and do this whilst in walking mode, your controls to crack the safe or assemble the mines will simply not work.

The only thing I can praise about the game are it's graphics and it's story oh and about that! I finished the last level last night and it loaded a cutscene in game, but the AI kept getting stuck on one of the textures which means that the cutscene was just stuck and my camera was stuck on the guy who was stuck and kept clipping through the catwalk so basically, I couldn't actually finish the game properly and so I had to look up the endings on youtube, absolutely redicolous given how old this game is now!

One other thing I forgot to mention is that for the JBA which is the organisation you're working for but are actually a double agent, you have to visit and carry out objectives within their safehouse 4 times! 4 times! That's just repetitive and it's confusing trying to get to know your way around it especially for the final level seeing as the map on your opsat is just plain awful.

So all in all, this game is worth playing I believe, but not on PC. Get Double Agent Version 1 on Xbox 360 or PS3 but not PC, it is just too buggy and it will annoy the hell out of you otherwise!

One final note, there are actually two versions of Double agent, version 1 is on Xbox 360, PS3 and PC and version 2 is on Xbox, PS2, gamecube and wii. Version two was done by Ubisoft Montreal and as a result, I've been told that version 2 is much much better than version 1 and it is a completely different game with a completely different level layout even though they share the same name, apparently it feels more like Chaos Theory so I can't wait to check that out at some point.

The bugs in this game make it unacceptable and it is a dissapointment given how great the last splinter cell was, only thing that holds it up are the graphics, the story, voice acting and I guess the level design.

All in all, this game gets a 4/10 for me on PC as even though the story was very good, the gameplay was littered with bugs, bad stealth mechanics and felt nothing like its predecessors.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game.  The level designs and concepts were great.  But the huge number of bugs/glitches/annoyances managed to suck all the fun out of this game.  I regularly I had to do internet searches on how to get around various problems so that I could progress in the game.

The game crashes frequently.  And the saves sometimes get into some sort of corrupted state so that you have no choice but find a previous save (if you have one) and replay parts of the game.

And if the save system wasn't so bad, this could be tolerable.  But quick saves don't work at all (apparently related to what drive you have the game installed on).  So you have to do manual saves and the saves don't get any sort of name and just appear in an unnecessarily small window (can see 4 at a time) in a random order (not even by save date) -- a total pain if you need to find the 2nd or 3rd last save so that you can replay to work around a problem.

And the final level was just a travesty.  The game crashed in so many places and saves got corrupted.  You work around all of that and then you finally difuse the bomb and then the game just freezes -- nothing.  You have to use task manager to shut down the game and restart yet again.  Then finally found out that you had to change screen resolution to 800x600 just before you completed the final task so that could see the final cutscene and progess to the bonus mission.

I can't believe that a product ever got released like this and obviously received such little support from the developers.  I don't really care whether this was Steam's fault, the publisher's fault or the developer's fault.  But the result is that a potentially very engaging game has become an epic fail.

reviewText:
I have always been a major Tom Clancy fan and the SC series is really the only one still somewhat intact. At first glance this is just another sh***ty Ubisoft port, but if you take some time to make the proper tweaks to the configuration files ( I know its not the way it should be, but this game is worth it) than this game really becomes one of the best in the SC series and a proper PC version. It has that the same mechanics as Chaos Theory (variable speeds, lockpicking, hacking) with a very interesting plot and mission setup. I love wandering around the JBA HQ in-between missions and suddenly realizing your somewhere you shouldn't be and find a hidden objective, the game doesn't hold your hand through this you just have to figure it out. As always with SC play on the hardest difficulty for that super-tense experience.

Refer to this page for graphic tweaks and other fixes:
http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Tom_Clancy%27s_Splinter_Cell:_Double_Agent

You can also look up how to force 'ultra-high' settings, which are not guaranteed to work but do make this game look stunning for a 2006 release.

If SC 7 is ever coming I hope the devs look back at this title and Chaos Theory, not Blacklist and Conviction which were still fun and gorgeous but didn't have as much focus on stealth and planning.

I really hope we get Pandora Tommorow on Steam some day!
